messages.text:
my nvim init just uses .vimrc
```set runtimepath^=/.vim runtimepath+=~/.vim/after
let &packpath = &runtimepath
source ~/.vimrc```

messages.text: Thanks. I think you have convinced me to switch to nvim.

elements.text: Thanks. I think you have convinced me to switch to nvim.

messages.text: yeah. i’ve been using vim for a long time. lately, due to <@U9VG1AYSG> daily updates here, i looked at the nvim again and see if it works but with no expectations if my plugins and configs will work out of the box. i would probably give up immediately if nvim spits errors alien to me. surprised that not only there are no issues but it’s a lot smoother when it comes to newer features like async updates of completion.

elements.text: yeah. i’ve been using vim for a long time. lately, due to

daily updates here, i looked at the nvim again and see if it works but with no expectations if my plugins and configs will work out of the box. i would probably give up immediately if nvim spits errors alien to me. surprised that not only there are no issues but it’s a lot smoother when it comes to newer features like async updates of completion.

messages.text: i tried this asyncomplete in vim but disabled it and blamed the plugin for making vim pause a lot. with nvim, there are no pauses so it must be the vim thing. i thought nvim claims are just claims but it seems they really have better development than vim. for old features, you won’t miss nvim but once you need  new programming features like lsp completion, nvim becomes a better vim. the good thing is both vim and nvim work using the same .vimrc so it’s not really an issue to transition or to use one or the other from time to time.

elements.text: i tried this asyncomplete in vim but disabled it and blamed the plugin for making vim pause a lot. with nvim, there are no pauses so it must be the vim thing. i thought nvim claims are just claims but it seems they really have better development than vim. for old features, you won’t miss nvim but once you need  new programming features like lsp completion, nvim becomes a better vim. the good thing is both vim and nvim work using the same .vimrc so it’s not really an issue to transition or to use one or the other from time to time.

messages.text: just make sure that when you run nvim for the first time and it asks you if you are a vim user, just press (y)es so that it will use the locations of .vim and .vimrc and generate its init.vim which points to .vim and .vimrc

messages.text: let me know if it works in your config also. i’m keen to know if nvim is stable :wink:. vim has been a good editor for me for a long time. without lsp support, other plugins in vim is quiet ok. but i think the async support in nvim makes editing smoother because any subprocess won’t block the editing process.

messages.text: the nvim project took backward compatibility very seriously because they knew that nobody would use it if their existing vim configs and plugins did not work

elements.text: the nvim project took backward compatibility very seriously because they knew that nobody would use it if their existing vim configs and plugins did not work

messages.text: as for it's stability: I think you will find that their official releases are very conservative and extremely stable, but a large portion of the user base (including myself) is on nightly.  A lot of stuff only works on 0.5 which is not officially released yet.  In particular, the lua run-time requires 0.5, so anything that uses lua requires it

elements.text: as for it's stability: I think you will find that their official releases are very conservative and extremely stable, but a large portion of the user base (including myself) is on nightly.  A lot of stuff only works on 0.5 which is not officially released yet.  In particular, the lua run-time requires 0.5, so anything that uses lua requires it

messages.text: how’s the emacs with julia lsp? any idea compared to vim ecosystem

elements.text: how’s the emacs with julia lsp? any idea compared to vim ecosystem

messages.text: no idea about LSP, but I have been toying with the idea of switching to emacs with a completely vim-like user interface.  My thinking is that in vim, the user interface is wonderful, but the scripting and tooling sucks, whereas in emacs, the user interface sucks, but the scripting and tooling is vastly better.  Since the former problem is "fixable" and the latter isn't, emacs is ultimately "better".  However, it would likely take enormous effort for me to switch to emacs with a setup I find satisfactory, so I've been resisting.  On the other hand, while I have some reservations about lua, it is undeniably infinitely better than vimscript.  Additionally, Python is also a first class scripting option for nvim now.   So, I'm exploring whether I'm more satisfied with doing everything in lua before looking seriously at emacs.  I plan on switching my configuration file entirely to lua after the official release of nvim 0.5

messages.text: i find using julia-lsp terrible as the language server runs julia 100% all the time. it seems that it is unstable or there is a process that gets busy and never stops.

elements.text: i find using julia-lsp terrible as the language server runs julia 100% all the time. it seems that it is unstable or there is a process that gets busy and never stops.

messages.text: yeah, it's a disaster.  Ultimately I think the thing to do would be to use PackageCompiler with a reasonable set of pre-compile statements, and in fact I had done something to set up to make it easier to use that through nvim-lsp, but it's kind of a moot point becuase the whole thing is already so broken in the first place

elements.text: yeah, it's a disaster.  Ultimately I think the thing to do would be to use PackageCompiler with a reasonable set of pre-compile statements, and in fact I had done something to set up to make it easier to use that through nvim-lsp, but it's kind of a moot point becuase the whole thing is already so broken in the first place

messages.text: I reported a bunch of errors to LanguageServer.jl and they showed that the problem was actually with nvim-lsp not following the spec.  Haven't opened the issue there yet... but suffice it to say, I think LSP is going to be really painful to use for a long time

elements.text: I reported a bunch of errors to LanguageServer.jl and they showed that the problem was actually with nvim-lsp not following the spec.  Haven't opened the issue there yet... but suffice it to say, I think LSP is going to be really painful to use for a long time

messages.text: yeah. even in vscode, it makes things in a state of suspended animation. it just takes over the cpu when the language server kicks in. it can spawn several sub-julia too and this makes the computer crawl. terrible implementation i think. i think the best is to just run something similar to ctags which is offline. online thing although provides dynamism if not implemented properly is like a robot that becomes suicidal :wink:

elements.text: yeah. even in vscode, it makes things in a state of suspended animation. it just takes over the cpu when the language server kicks in. it can spawn several sub-julia too and this makes the computer crawl. terrible implementation i think. i think the best is to just run something similar to ctags which is offline. online thing although provides dynamism if not implemented properly is like a robot that becomes suicidal

messages.text: anyway, most of its lsp suggestions are not helpful. it’s not worth to have a busy cpu doing nothing and have those suggestions irritating to the eye.  i think i can just live with async completion. that’s good enough.

elements.text: anyway, most of its lsp suggestions are not helpful. it’s not worth to have a busy cpu doing nothing and have those suggestions irritating to the eye.  i think i can just live with async completion. that’s good enough.

attachments.title: My Julia setup for vim with YCM on Linux
attachments.text: Installation $ pip install jill --user -U $ jill install 1.3 lsp Plug 'ycm-core/YouCompleteMe' Plug 'ycm-core/lsp-examples' Plug 'JuliaEditorSupport/julia-vim', {'for': 'julia'} let g:ycm_language_server = [ \ { \ 'name': 'julia', \ 'filetypes': [ 'julia' ], \ 'project_root_files': [ 'Project.toml' ], \ 'cmdline': ['julia', '--startup-file=no', '--history-file=no', '-e', ' \ using LanguageServer; \ using Pkg; \ import StaticLint; \ ...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: My Julia setup for vim with YCM on Linux

messages.text: So the local symbol indexing (which loads every package in your env to query which symbols it defines) will go away soonish in favour of (optional) cloud indexing and a fast static-analysis fallback. There should also be fairly granular settings for what linter warnings are shown, but I don't know how you can set them in non-VSCode clients

elements.text: So the local symbol indexing (which loads every package in your env to query which symbols it defines) will go away soonish in favour of (optional) cloud indexing and a fast static-analysis fallback. There should also be fairly granular settings for what linter warnings are shown, but I don't know how you can set them in non-VSCode clients

messages.text: Hey guys, I posted on the <#C017Z6Q3WS3|pluto> channel, but got no answers. Does anyone know of any initiative to create a vim-mode for Pluto? It's the only thing that's keeping me from using it. I really like the vim-mode on Jupyter, I was wondering how hard it would be to port it to Pluto. Has anyone taken a look at it?
